frameDefinitions: This frame covers a step in a criminal process in which a  Judge decides whether the Accused should be released on bail, and, if so, what the amount of the bail should be.  '' 'Thorsen, of Grimstad, Norway, was granted $100,000 bail until June 18.'
A Speaker either agrees to or refuses to engage in a Proposed_action, proposed by an Interlocutor. '' 'They agreed to express their outrage with editorials in today's paper.'
A Speaker makes a commitment to an Addressee to carry out some future action.
Under some Condition, usually left implicit, a Responsible_party is required to perform some Duty.
A Cause (or associated Actor) causes an ongoing Process to temporarily stop.
A Duty is imposed on a Responsible_party according to a Principle which regulates how the Responsible_party should respond to a Situation.
frameExamples: Thorsen, of Grimstad, Norway, was granted $100,000 <t>bail</t> until June 18.
They <t>agreed</t> to express their outrage with editorials in today's paper.
You <t>promised</t> me you'd come to my graduation.
It is my <t>duty</t> to fight any attack on the Brotherhood .
They escaped total Soviet invasion and occupation only by entering into a separate agreement that <t>obligated</t> them to military action against the retreating German armies.
listRoleDefinitions: At the time of bail setting, the <fen>Accused</fen> is held without bail/bond, released on his/her own recognizance, or required to give the Court  a specific amount of money for bail.
The <fen>Judge</fen>, as head of  the Court, determines the <fen>Accused</fen>'s bail.
<fen>Status</fen> idenitifies the decision made with regard to bail.  The possible statuses are 'without bail/bond', 'on one's own recognizance', or a specific amount of money required for bail.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the bail setting occurs.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the bail setting occurs.
The <fen>Speaker</fen> is the person to whom a particular action has been proposed and who responds to the request or offer made.
This is the person who proposed the <fen>Proposed_action</fen>  to the <fen>Speaker</fen> and to whom the <fen>Speaker</fen> communicates  their response.
The <fen>Proposed_action</fen> is an action that the <fen>Speaker</fen> would perform if they were to accept or refuse the request or offer.
The time interval during which the <fen>Speaker</fen> makes their verbal response concerning the proposed action.
The location in which the <fen>Speaker</fen>  gives their verbal response to the proposed action.

The Speaker is the person who commits him/herself to do something.  Speaker is usually the External Argument of predicative uses of the target or the Genitive modifier of a noun: <fex name='Speaker'>Jo</fex> made a <t>promise</t> to me. <fex name='Speaker'>Jo</fex> <t>promised</t> me she would cook dinner. <fex name='Speaker'>Jo's</fex> <t>promise</t> to cook dinner came to nothing.

The Speaker's commitment can be made to an Addressee.  With those words which allow this frame element to be expressed, Addressee usually occurs as a PP Complement headed by <ment>to</ment> or the (Indirect) Object of verbs: Kim made a <t>promise</t> <fex name='Addressee'>to me</fex>. Kim <t>promised</t> <fex name='Addressee'>me</fex> that everything would be okay.

An expression of the commitment made by the Speaker expresses the frame element Message.  Message is expressed as a finite or non-finite clausal Complement or an NP Object: I <t>swore</t> <fex name='Message'>that I would never make the same mistake again</fex>. The owner finally <t>consented</t> <fex name='Message'>to sell the business</fex>. They <t>threatened</t> <fex name='Message'>revenge</fex>.
Topic expressions are not very frequent in this frame. They can occur with noun targets. Jo made endless <t>promises</t> <fex name='Topic'>about working harder at school</fex>.

As with other frames in the Communication domain, the <t>Medium</t> of communication may be expressed. Medium is the physical entity or channel used to transmit the Message. Bob <t>threatened</t> the workers <fex name='Medium'>in Spanish</fex>.
The time period during which the <fen>Speaker</fen> makes the commitment.
The location in which the <fen>Speaker</fen> makes the commitment.
The person who must perform the <fen>Duty</fen>.
The action that the <fen>Responsible_party</fen> is obligated to perform.
The time interval during which the Responsibly_party is obligated to fulfill the Duty.
A location in which the <fen>Responsible_party</fen> has a specified <fen>Duty</fen> .
A force, process, or event that produces the interruption.
The <fen>Process</fen> goes into a paused state due to the <fen>Cause</fen> or <fen>Actor</fen>.
An entity which participates in a <fen>Cause</fen>, perhaps volitionally and perhaps not, but effectively causing the interruption.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the interruption occurs.
Where the interruption takes place.
The person who must perform the <fen>Duty</fen>.
The action that the <fen>Responsible_party</fen> is obligated to perform.
The <fen>Obligator</fen> is the person who imposes the <fen>Duty</fen> on the <fen>Responsible_party</fen>.
A state of affairs that results in the <fen>Responsible_party</fen> being obligated to carry out the <fen>Duty</fen> in accordance with the <fen>Principle</fen>.
A regulating idea  (which may be instantiated as a document)  that the <fen>Responsible_party</fen> is subject to.
The time interval during which  the <fen>Duty</fen> is imposed on the <fen>Responsible_party</fen>  by the <fen>Obligator</fen> or the <fen>Situation</fen>.
A location in which the <fen>Responsible_party</fen> has a specified <fen>Duty</fen> .
listRoleExamples: Judge Duncan fixed <fex>the doctor's</fex> bail at one million dollars.
<fex>Judge Duncan</fex> fixed the doctor's bail at one million dollars.
Judge Duncan fixed the doctor's bail <fex>at one million dollars</fex>.

The chancellor <fex>yesterday</fex> promised to increase defence spending in real terms next
year.
The july framework has reaffirmed what was promised <fex>at Doha</fex>.
My job is <fex>to get to the other side of the bridge</fex>.
<fex>At that time</fex> men were obligated to marry women from their own community.
I almost forgot to tell you that <fex>in Sweden</fex> we are obligated to spend atleast 7.5 months in the army for training.
<fex>Leaving the page after you've clicked 'Download'</fex> will interrupt the transfer.
Leaving the page after you've clicked 'Download' will interrupt <fex>the transfer</fex>.
In such cases <fex>the server</fex> will automatically interrupt the process.
The winning bid committed <fex>her</fex> to paint an oil portrait for the high bidder.

Had she really said the word which pledged her <fex>to marry Horace Holmcroft in a
fortnight</fex>?
<fex>She</fex> pledged him to pay her the money back.
<fex>Admitting a genocide was occurring</fex>  would have obligated them, based on their signing the December 1948 Convention on the repression of genocide, to do something about it.
And <fex>no law</fex> obligated him to talk to the police, let alone the media

The City Council <fex>then</fex> obligated themselves to have the sewers made ready and the
streets leveled off without any additional cost to the Sisters.
<fex>At Dayton</fex>, the parties obligated themselves to respect and promote fulfillment of the annexes.
